title: The Cloaca Maxima: Rome's Great Sewer
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Cloaca Maxima: Rome's Great Sewer usable.

hook.text: Rome's main sewer, the Cloaca Maxima, was built in 600 BC and is still in use todayâ€”2,600 years of continuous operation.

buildup.text: Originally an open channel draining a swamp, it was enclosed with stone arches large enough to drive an ox cart through.

discovery.text: The sewer collected rainwater and wastewater from public toilets and baths, flushing everything into the Tiber River.

twist.text: Romans had no germ theory. They built sewers to fight bad smells, not germs. It workedâ€”for the wrong reasons.

climax.text: The Cloaca Maxima inspired every urban sewer that followed. Modern Rome still uses its route for drainage.

punchline.text: They solved a problem they didn't understandâ€”and it still works.

quiz.question: Why did Romans build the Cloaca Maxima sewer system?
options: To eliminate foul smells they believed caused disease
To prevent the Tiber River from flooding the city
To transport goods underground through the city
